;法国导演 Justine Triet 成为第三位获得戛纳电影节金棕榈奖的女导演“或者在星期六，击败其他 20 部影片角逐最高奖项。”

;

;特里特在她的获奖感言中批评法国对养老金改革的抗议“以令人震惊的方式遭到否认和镇压”并呼吁为年轻电影制作人腾出更多空间。

;

;“我们必须为他们腾出空间，15​​ 年前我在一个稍微不那么敌对的世界里得到了空间，在那里仍然有可能错误并重新开始，”她说。

;

;特里特击败了是枝裕和、肯·洛奇和维姆·文德斯等资深导演赢得了奖项，他们都至少获得过一次金棕榈奖.

;

;她加入了新西兰的简·坎皮恩和法国的朱莉娅·杜库尔诺，成为第三位赢得比赛的女性，今年的比赛包括创纪录的七位女导演。

;

;大奖赛，仅次于金棕榈奖的第二高奖项是英国导演乔纳森·格雷泽 (Jonathan Glazer) 的《感兴趣区》(Zone of Interest)，该片讲述了一个生活在奥斯威辛集中营附近的家庭。

;

;两部获奖影片的主演都是德国演员桑德拉·惠勒 (Sandra Hueller)，她在《解剖学》(Anatomy) 中饰演of a Fall 饰演一位作家，她是丈夫死亡的主要嫌疑人，而在“感兴趣区”中，她是奥斯威辛死亡集中营指挥官的妻子。

;

;但是，最佳女演员奖却落空了Merve Dizdar，他在土耳其导演 Nuri Bilge Ceylan 的《About Dry Grasses》中饰演土耳其一个偏僻村庄的老师。

;

;Perfect Days：日本资深演员在 Wim Wenders 的东京故事中大放异彩

;

;最佳男演员奖颁给了著名的 Koji Yakusho，他在导演 Wim Wenders 的《完美时光》中饰演东京的厕所清洁工。

;

;芬兰的 Aki Kaurismaki 的《落叶》，他在十多年后重返竞争舞台, 获得了评审团奖。

;

;他的奖项由代表他的悲喜剧的两位主要明星领奖。

;

;法国-越南导演 Tran Anh Hung 带回家由朱丽叶·比诺什 (Juliette Binoche) 和伯努瓦·马吉梅尔 (Benoit Magimel) 夫妇主演的法国美食电影《火锅》(The Pot-au-Feu) 获得最佳导演奖。

;

;在介绍最佳剧本时，演员约翰·C·赖利 (John C Reilly) 表达了他对罢工好莱坞作家的支持大约一分钟的无言模仿，然后说：“我们刚刚经历的是没有编剧的电影会是什么样子。”

;

;那个奖项颁给了坂本裕二的日本入场怪物，由是枝裕和执导，继围绕两个男学生的友谊产生一系列误解之后。

;

;今年的闭幕电影是皮克斯的元素元素，这是一部讲述四种元素共同生活的城市的动画长片，由莉亚·刘易斯和马穆杜·阿西配音。

;

;瑞典导演鲁本·奥斯特伦德是今年的评委会主席，他曾承诺不会从他的成员那里泄露消息，其中包括 Ducournau 和演员保罗·达诺（法贝尔曼一家）和布丽·拉尔森（惊奇队长）。< /p>;

;就纯粹的名人影响力而言，今年的节日是多年来最盛大的节日之一，好莱坞传奇人物哈里森·福特、马丁·斯科塞斯、罗伯特·德尼罗、伊莎贝拉·罗西里尼和西恩·潘都登上了红地毯。

;教皇弗朗西斯在星期六恢复了常规约会，一天后由于

;

;教皇举行了一些私人会议，包括与来自乔治敦大学的来访者会面，他们在镇上与耶稣会会刊开会。

;

;据梵蒂冈新闻报道，来自世界各地的一些诗人、作家和电影导演出席了会议，其中包括导演马丁·斯科塞斯及其家人。弗朗西斯后来被视频拍到到达国家广播公司 RAI 的工作室录制采访，他对外面的祝福者热情地微笑。

;

;梵蒂冈确认这位 86 岁的教皇发烧引发了人们的担忧弗朗西斯的健康。上一次他严重发烧是在 3 月份，这位 86 岁的教皇被紧急送往医院，被诊断出患有急性支气管炎。他接受了静脉注射抗生素，三天后出院。

;

;梵蒂冈已确认教皇将于周日主持五旬节弥撒，并将于周一会见意大利总统塞尔吉奥·马塔雷拉。

;< p>;同样在周六，法国主教团表示，教皇弗朗西斯接受了斯特拉斯堡大主教吕克·拉威尔因被指控在职期间行为不当而辞职的请求，但没有提供进一步的理由。

;

;拉威尔的辞职是在教皇对去年夏天在阿尔萨斯担任大主教。

;

;据阿尔萨斯最新消息报报道，拉威尔被指控经常缺席斯特拉斯堡以及在办公室的独裁行为。

;

;乌克兰总统沃洛德米尔泽伦斯基在梵蒂冈会见教皇

;

;教区的天主教徒在网上请愿呼吁拉威尔辞职。

;

;他于 2017 年在阿尔萨斯上任。

;

;拉威尔大主教甚至在法国的主教会议就此问题表态之前，他就教会的虐待问题采取了明确的立场。

;

;他解雇了教区的财务总监，并引起了轰动在短短一年多的时间内辅助主教。

;在 Extinction Rebellion 气候组织的抗议活动中，超过 1,500 人被捕荷兰警方表示，周六海牙。

;

;

;

;抗议者中有几位荷兰名人，包括 Carice van Houten，她因在热门电视剧《权力的游戏》中饰演梅丽珊卓而为人所知。

;

;Extinction Rebellion在伦勃朗的画作旁边举行气候抗议活动

;

;荷兰新闻社 ANP 报道说她被捕但后来被允许回家。

;它没有具体说明她是否属于那些将被逮捕的人之一

;

; Sun, 28 May 2023 04:20:02 +0800 Amid Micron ban, US working with allies to beat China’s ‘economic coercion’: commerce secretaryhttps://www.scmp.com/news/china/article/3222070/amid-micron-ban-us-working-allies-beat-chinas-economic-coercion-commerce-secretary?utm_source=rss_feed
;;2023.05.28 04:15;
;;

;华盛顿正与世界各地的盟友合作，以克服中国最近对美国半导体的禁令美国商务部长吉娜·雷蒙多 (Gina Raimondo) 周六表示，美光公司的主要基础设施项目受到了影响。

;

;太平洋经济合作组织 (APEC) 论坛在密歇根州底特律结束。

;

;“我们不会容忍它，我们也不认为它会成功。”

;

;美国“密切与合作伙伴合作应对这一具体挑战以及与中国非市场做法相关的所有挑战”，她补充说，当被问及北京试图通过禁止美国公司同时向其在诸如此类国家的竞争对手开放市场来在华盛顿与其盟友之间制造隔阂时韩国。

;

;北京对美光的禁令被广泛视为对拜登政府对某些尖端半导体的出口限制的报复，旨在扼杀中国在战略技术方面的能力。

;

;周五，中国商务部部长王文涛在亚太经合组织会议期间会见了韩国外长。

;

;“双方重点就维护产业链供应链稳定、加强双边、区域和多边合作，”根据中国商务部的一份声明。声明称，“中国推进高水平对外开放，将为包括韩国在内的世界各国提供新机遇”。

;

;王毅表示，北京愿同首尔一道，深化双边贸易投资合作。维护产业链供应链稳定。根据贸易部数据，韩国约 40% 的芯片出口销往中国。

;

;雷蒙多周六在底特律发表上述言论，正值美国主导的一项旨在对抗中国对中国影响的经济倡议一周年。

;

;随着贸易官员在底特律会面，美中关系继续解冻

;

;经过近一年的多轮紧张谈判，14 个国家的印太周六的经济框架就建立可持续和有弹性的供应链达成了有史以来的第一个协议，重点是战略项目，包括关键矿产和半导体。然而，贸易分歧依然存在。

;

;“我很高兴今天下午宣布，我们已经基本完成 IPEF 供应链协议的谈判，”雷蒙多在四个小时的讨论结束后的媒体吹风会上说.闭门的部长级会议涵盖贸易、供应链、绿色经济和反腐败。

;

;美国总统拜登于去年 5 月推出了该框架，当时将其描述为“编写新规则通过与拥有民主等“共同价值观”的国家合作，打造“21 世纪经济”。

;

;其参与国家包括澳大利亚、文莱、斐济、印度、印度尼西亚、日本、马来西亚、新西兰、菲律宾、新加坡、韩国、泰国和越南。它们加起来占全球国内生产总值的 40%。

;

;Raimondo 将周六的发展描述为“非常重要的事情”。

;

;“通过 IPEF 深化我们的合作，这拟议的供应链协议将改善美国企业的商业环境，推动对美国公司和工人的投资，加强和支持美国的就业机会，并帮助美国保持全球竞争力。

;

;该协议将建立一个IPEF 供应链委员会负责协调特定行业的行动，以在关键行业的供应链中建立弹性和竞争力。

;

;它还将建立 Raimondo 所说的“铁定”IPEF 供应链响应网络为 IPEF 合作伙伴提供紧急沟通渠道。

;

;该协议进一步呼吁成立劳工权利咨询委员会，以提供新机制来解决劳动力培训、技能提升和劳工权利问题。

;

;“我们都在 Covid 期间学到了艰难的方法，如果你在供应链危机期间不能迅速和透明地沟通是多么困难，”Raimondo 说。

;

;美国和亚洲国家之间的分歧使 IPEF 谈判复杂化

;

;上周五，王毅在亚太经合组织会议间隙与美国贸易代表凯瑟琳·戴伊进行了一对一对话，提出了对 IPEF 的担忧。

;

;中国是世界第二大经济体最大的经济体，将 IPEF 视为美国遏制其竞争对手经济扩张的尝试。

;

;许多 IPEF 合作伙伴也是贸易协定的成员，例如跨太平洋伙伴关系全面进步协定 (CPTPP) 和区域综合协定经济伙伴关系（RCEP）。与 IPEF 不同，这两项协议都提供自由市场准入和降低关税。

;

;2016 年，拜登的前任唐纳德·特朗普让美国退出 CPTPP 的前身 12 国跨太平洋伙伴关系协定，以保护国内制造业及其工人。最初的协议是在奥巴马政府期间签署的，目的是对抗中国的崛起。

;

;2021 年上任的拜登已经排除了重新加入该组织的可能性。但是，中国已经申请加入。北京也是 RCEP 的成员，其中包括日本和韩国。

;

;美国参议员预测，中国将被排除在跨太平洋贸易集团之外

;

;虽然 IPEF 与会者在底特律就供应链达成共识后，发展中经济体继续寻求更多地进入美国市场并降低关税。

;

;印度是美国在印太地区的重要盟友，但没有参加IPEF 周六进行贸易谈判。纳伦德拉·莫迪 (Narendra Modi) 政府在国内面临来自一些民间社会和其他团体的压力，要求其退出贸易谈判。

;

;领导 IPEF 贸易谈判的美国贸易特使泰将这一框架描述为“不是传统的贸易协议”，并表示其目标从一开始就“将因此有所不同”。

;

;“我们不只是试图最大限度地提高效率和自由化，”Tai 说。 “我们正在努力促进可持续性、弹性和包容性。”

;

;“我知道改变是可怕的。无论如何，变化正在我们身边发生。”

;在超过掌舵十年，但人们普遍预计他仍将是巴尔干国家最有权势的政治人物。

;

;Vucic 的塞尔维亚进步党 (SNS) 去年以压倒性优势赢得议会选举，但一直定期被指控腐败，以及最近因两起枪击事件引发的大规模抗议而承受越来越大的压力。

;

;尽管不再担任党主席，武契奇仍将是塞尔维亚总统和该国最有影响力的政治家——就像他在他辞去总理职务，于 2017 年成为总统。

;

;这位自 2012 年以来一直担任 SNS 负责人的 53 岁人士表示，他不会离开他帮助建立的政党。

;

;“无论你们做什么，我都会一直陪在你们身边，”武契奇在一次电视大会上告诉党员们。

;

;“我只是认为需要一种稍微不同的方法来团结一个更多的人想要为一个爱国的、成功的塞尔维亚的胜利而战。”

;

;Vucic 已经宣布计划组建一个全国性的运动，计划包括著名的知识分子、艺术家和其他公众数字，并有望逐渐与 SNS 结合。

;

;根据分析人士的说法，武契奇比他的政党更受欢迎，后者经常成为腐败指控的目标，新的联盟将有助于重塑品牌形象

;

;塞尔维亚：大规模枪击事件后交出了 13,500 件武器

;

;“这是克服塞尔维亚进步党内部可能酝酿的危机的一种方式”独立选举监督机构 CESID 的负责人博扬·克拉卡尔 (Bojan Klacar) 告诉法新社。

;

;“通过发起一场新运动，他想确保自己在办公室获得另一项授权，”克拉卡尔说。< /p>;

;Vucic 的反对者指责他越来越依赖专制措施来使反对派陷入混乱，并使媒体和国家机构处于他的控制之下。

;

;Vucic 的执政党也承受着越来越大的压力上个月，接二连三的枪击事件引发了一场反对政府的群众运动，导致数万人走上街头。

;

;国防部长 Milos Vucevic，塞尔维亚第二大城市诺维市前市长悲伤，当选为 SNS 党的新总统，他立即拒绝了抗议者。

;

;新的 SNS 领导人拒绝了一些抗议者在新选举前成立过渡政府的要求，他说政府不能“脱离街头，通过暴力”当选。

; Sun, 28 May 2023 03:50:02 +0800 China should tread carefully in Afghanistan or risk becoming the latest addition to ‘graveyard of empires’https://www.scmp.com/comment/opinion/article/3221776/china-should-tread-carefully-afghanistan-or-risk-becoming-latest-addition-graveyard-empires?utm_source=rss_feed
;;2023.05.28 03:30;
;;

;塔利班在阿富汗重新掌权已经快两年了，看到经过 20 年的国家建设，美国及其盟国在一片混乱中离开。

;

;大自然厌恶真空，而中国乐于填补真空。当喀布尔落入塔利班之手时，西方圈子并没有忽视中国保持其大使馆开放，根据塔利班发言人的说法，中国当时承诺“加强”与新政权的关系。

;

;阿富汗为中国提供了很多机会。喀布尔一个稳定和乐于接受的政府可以提供一个机会，在这个资源丰富但欠发达国家投资利润丰厚的基础设施、能源和采矿项目。例如，今年 1 月，塔利班与中石油旗下的新疆中亚石油天然气公司签署了从阿姆河盆地开采石油的合同。

;

;中国长期以来一直将阿富汗视为未来“一带一路”倡议成员。该倡议于 2013 年启动，旨在通过中亚和南亚将亚洲与非洲和欧洲连接起来。

;

;本月早些时候，中国和巴基斯坦同意将该倡议中的基础设施项目扩展到阿富汗，有可能开放该国高达数十亿美元的投资机会。这包括决定将价值 600 亿美元的中巴经济走廊延伸至这个内陆国家。

;

;在外交方面，中国欢迎塔利班代表，并鼓励国际社会取消制裁并更好地与该政权互动。然而，官方承认暂时似乎仍未谈及。

;

;这表明北京比几十年前更加自信，愿意在经济和政治上进行干预以巩固其在该地区的权威。与此同时，塔利班迫切渴望获得国际认可和投资机会，以试图重建国家并解决其经济和人道主义危机。

;

;但这种关系并不像任何一方那样简单明了小心承认。塔利班统治的阿富汗受到若干问题的困扰，这些问题使投资或改善关系变得极其困难。

;

;该国继续努力应对人道主义危机，这场危机已使大部分人口陷入贫困。联合国表示，超过 2800 万阿富汗人需要某种形式的人道主义援助。

;

;塔利班让所有阿富汗人的生活变得更糟。现在外援枯竭

;

;形势确实严峻。联合国秘书长安东尼奥·古特雷斯最近在多哈举行的一次会议上表达了对解决危机所需资金不足的担忧，并指出在人道主义应急计划 46 亿美元的目标之外，从捐助者那里“仅收到了 2.94 亿美元”。

;

;就中国而言，中国承诺在 2021 年向阿富汗提供 3100 万美元的人道主义援助。但是，该国目前的局势阻碍了长期基础设施项目所需的那种稳定。

;< p>; 这场危机与塔利班对妇女人权的严厉镇压交织在一起。它禁止妇女接受中学和高等教育，也禁止妇女工作，使数百万人进一步陷入贫困。塔利班最近决定限制妇女在联合国工作，这也意味着许多人无法获得挽救生命的食物、水和药品。

;

;2 月，中国与更广泛的国际社会一起呼吁塔利班结束对妇女和教育的限制。在与伊朗的联合声明中，它呼吁“阿富汗统治者组建一个所有民族和政治团体都真正参与其中的包容性政府，并取消所有对妇女、少数民族和其他宗教的歧视措施”。

;

; 对中国而言，一个可以说更为紧迫的问题是自塔利班掌权以来伊斯兰极端主义在阿富汗的兴起。中国警惕塔利班窝藏极端主义团体的习惯，尤其是来自中国新疆地区的极端主义团体。

;

;据报道，多年来，中国政府拘留了多达 100 万维吾尔族人，维吾尔族是一个穆斯林少数民族。职业培训的幌子。据报道，中国还向塔利班施压，要求其拒绝支持维吾尔武装分子，并更广泛地打击极端主义，以换取官方承认。

;

;此外，中国公民在阿富汗工作时面临风险。在一个案例中，身份不明的男子去年年底袭击了喀布尔的龙眼酒店——一家深受中国公民欢迎的酒店，导致中国政府呼吁其公民“尽快”离开阿富汗。

;

; 1 月，在喀布尔的阿富汗外交部外发生恐怖袭击，造成 5 人丧生，中国代表团本来预计会到那里。中国外交部对此表示关切，并表示希望阿富汗政府保护包括中国公民在内的所有国家的公民。

;

;这些袭击表明塔利班要么无力应对阿富汗境内的恐怖主义，要么根本就没有能力对此很感兴趣。

;

;长期以来，阿富汗一直被称为帝国的墓地。该国仍然不稳定，塔利班拒绝尊重人权、组建包容性政府和打击极端主义团体将确保这种情况继续下去。

;

;至少在经济上，这可能意味着中国将面临同样的待遇。如果北京想避免这种命运，就应该谨慎行事。

;Twitter exited the voluntary European Union's Code of Practice on Disinformation, the bloc's Internal Market Commissioner Thierry Breton said.

;

;“Twitter leaves EU voluntary Code of Practice against disinformation. But obligations remain”, Breton said on his Twitter account late on Friday. “You can run but you can't hide”.

;

;New Twitter CEO Linda Yaccarino 'excited' to help to transform platform

;

;He said that beyond voluntary commitments, fighting disinformation will become a legal obligation as of August 25 under the EU Digital Services Act. Twitter will qualify as a “very large online platform,” requiring the company to address harmful content and submit annual risk assessments to the commission.

;

;“Our teams will be ready for enforcement,” Breton tweeted.

;

;Musk's massive job cuts at Twitter – including the exodus of the company's entire Brussels office – have raised concerns about whether it will be able to make the necessary changes to comply with the EU's rules. ; Sat, 27 May 2023 23:50:02 +0800 Hong Kong’s Civic Party folds after 17 years of championing opposition causeshttps://www.scmp.com/news/hong-kong/politics/article/3222062/hong-kongs-civic-party-folds-after-17-years-championing-opposition-causes?utm_source=rss_feed
;;2023.05.27 22:51;
;;

;Hong Kong's Civic Party, once the second largest in the now-decimated opposition camp, has disbanded after 17 years, with its chairman urging residents to remain hopeful, “live in truth and believe in tomorrow”.

;

;The organisation began to wind itself up after all but one of its 31 members voted for the motion to dissolve at an at extraordinary general meeting on Saturday.

;

;“After completing the final procedures, the Civic Party will disappear from the world,” chairman and co-founder Alan Leong Kah-kit said.

;

;Leong said the fate of the party was sealed when no members came forward to run for chairman or the executive committee last year, leaving it without leadership successors who could organise fundraising.

;

;“Given the constraints of our financial situation, to voluntarily wind up is really not a surprise,” he said, adding the party' assets were in the five figures and would be donated to charities when the liquidation was completed.

;

;The party championed the cause of universal suffrage and the rule of law since its founding by six lawmakers in 2006 and won over 70 Legislative Council seats in seven elections, clear evidence its platform resonated with voters, he said.

;

;Leong also expressed gratitude to residents who had supported the organisation at a time when democratic development was at a low ebb.

;

;“While the Civic Party has not accomplished what we set out to do, there is a time for everything,” he wrote in his chairman's report. “The world is ever changing. History will tell. Today, the Civic Party is bidding Hong Kong farewell. We hope Hong Kong people will live in the moment with a hopeful and not too heavy heart. Live in truth and believe in tomorrow.”

;

;The future of the party became uncertain when Beijing imposed the national security law on Hong Kong in 2020, targeting acts of secession, subversion, terrorism and collusion with foreign forces, following the anti-government protests the year before.

;

;In 2021, four core members – former lawmakers Alvin Yeung Ngok-kiu, Jeremy Tam Man-ho and Kwok Ka-ki, and ex-district councillor Lee Yue-shun – were charged with subversion over their roles in an unofficial primary to select candidates to run for Legco seats. Authorities described the run-off as part of a plot to paralyse the government.

;

;Hong Kong's opposition Civic Party rocked by resignation of 11 councillors

;

;During lengthy bail proceedings, the four defendants announced they had quit the party and politics altogether. They later made an emotional appeal for the party to disband, arguing the move would help protect members from possible prosecution. A chain of events that began in 2020 had consistently proven the party had no future, they claimed.

;

;At the time, Leong said he had repeatedly talked about dissolving the party with members but they decided instead “to walk together with Hongkongers” while adjusting course in a changed political environment.

;

;The party was long associated with barristers, as several co-founders and chairs worked in the profession, including Leong, Audrey Eu Yuet-mee and Ronny Tong Ka-wah.

;

;The three initially came together in 2003 to oppose the government's plan to implement Article 23 of the Basic Law, which requires the city to enact legislation similar to the national security law introduced by Beijing three years ago. The administration ultimately shelved the bill after a fierce backlash from the public.

;

;The party positioned itself as an alternative governance force and set an ultimate goal of becoming a ruling one when it formed in 2006. The following year, the opposition camp chose Leong to run against Donald Tsang Yam-kuen in the chief executive poll, a long shot aimed at exposing the nature of the “small-circle election”.

;

;Hong Kong's Civic Party pledges to focus on livelihood over political reform

;

;But the party then began to take a more confrontational approach to constitutional development, as evidenced by its opposition to a political reform plan floated by the Democratic Party after it struck a compromise with Beijing in 2010.

;

;In 2015, a year after a civil disobedience movement calling for universal suffrage paralysed parts of the city, Tong quit the party to pursue a more centrist political path and became a member of the Executive Council, the city leader's key decision-making body.

;

;Tong on Saturday said it was a pity that the party was disbanding.

;

;“I intended to establish the party to take care of those Hongkongers who take the middle stance in politics … and communicate with Beijing to reach consensus on pushing constitutional development,” he said. “But the party deviated from the ideology, and I have been advising them to return on the right track for over a decade but in vain.”

;

;Residents should not blame the national security law for the death of the party, he said, arguing the opposition camp had become more radical in recent years, which might have led to Beijing introducing the legislation.

;

;More than 50 civil groups have folded since the national security law was introduced.

;

;Barrister Stephen Char Shik-ngor, another founding member, said that while the collapse of the party was regrettable nothing remained forever.

;

;“We have given our all over the past decade and tried all we could,” he said. “Whether we succeed or not is no longer the most important thing of all.”

;

;While Char said he respected Tong's opinions of the party, he said its dissolution offered authorities the chance to reflect on whether having only one voice in politics would help society improve.

;

;“Some may find the governance effective, but is it really a good thing?” he said.

;

;Hong Kong opposition down and out, trying to find its place

;

;Separately, Secretary for Home and Youth Affairs Alice Mak Mei-kuen on Saturday slammed Britain for criticising the city's revamp of the district councils in its six-monthly parliamentary report on Hong Kong. The overhaul will see most directly elected members replaced with appointed ones.

;

;Britain was not in a position to criticise the revamp given the practice of appointing members to the municipal bodies was introduced by the British colonial government, she said.

;

;“Maybe they have forgotten. I was appointed during the colonial era as well. Therefore, they should be in favour of the appointment system and should not renege on their words,” she said.

;

;Mak stressed the revamp could diversify the background of district councillors and allow the government to better understand public sentiment.

;Henry Kissinger remains fixated on China more than 50 years after his secret, groundbreaking trip to Beijing in 1971.

;

;Unlike half a century ago, when he triangulated Beijing against Moscow with the reopening of direct diplomacy, tilting the Cold War balance of power, the former US secretary of state is now worried about a superpower war with Beijing.

;

;Kissinger, who turns 100 on Saturday, has repeatedly warned of “catastrophic consequences” of a military confrontation between the two giants, which he has said are in “the foothills of a cold war”.

;

;While many say his influence has dwindled in Washington, this is not the case in China.

;

;“When Kissinger talks about the world situation and China, which he still does regularly, we should definitely listen to him with veneration and attention,” said a Chinese diplomat, who requested anonymity because of the sensitivity of the matter.

;

;Path to military conflict diverted by Xi-Biden summit: Kissinger

;

;Xie Feng, China's new ambassador to Washington, visited Kissinger in Kent, Connecticut on Friday to offer Beijing's congratulations for his 100th birthday. The two sides had an “in-depth exchange of views on China-US relations and international and regional issues of common concern”, the Chinese embassy said.

;

;According to observers, the fact that Kissinger has remained more popular and influential in China than at home underscores the importance Beijing has attached to maintaining ties with the US, despite their ideological and geopolitical rivalry.

;

;They often point to the veteran statesman's extraordinary ability to cultivate close ties with five generations of top Chinese leaders, from Mao Zedong and Deng Xiaoping to Jiang Zemin, Hu Jintao and Xi Jinping.

;

;During his last China visit in November 2019, soon before the start of the Covid-19 pandemic, Chinese President Xi Jinping hailed Kissinger's “historical contribution” to bilateral ties and his “profound historical insights and deep understanding of traditional Chinese culture”.

;

;Kissinger praised Xi and expounded on his favourite topic: how to avoid an unintended conflict between great powers. He also boasted that he had visited China nearly 100 times over the last 50 years.

;

;Few Americans had played a more prominent role in US-China relations than Kissinger, said Wang Huiyao, the founder and president of the Centre for China and Globalisation, a government-linked think tank in Beijing.

;

;Calling him “the greatest diplomat of the 20th century”, Wang, a former Chinese government official, said that from Beijing's perspective, Kissinger's biggest contribution was the trailblazing role he played in brokering the historic rapprochement with China.

;

;Wang said Kissinger would be remembered fondly for his vision, his profound understanding of China and extraordinary ability to make peace, as well as for helping to open China to the world and promoting bilateral cooperation, which helped bring about China's rise as the world's second largest economy.

;

;Paraphrasing Deng during his first state visit to the United States in 1979, Wang noted that countries that had sought good ties with the US had developed.

;

;Wang said despite criticism of Kissinger's 1973 Nobel Peace Prize for a short-lived Vietnam peace agreement, his peacemaking efforts between China and the US were a turning point in the Cold War and merited the award.

;

;According to Wang, Kissinger played a “unique and indispensable” role in China's handling of US affairs, with Chinese leaders and top diplomats viewing him as an intermediary with the White House and seeking his counsel regularly, especially in times of crisis.

;

;“China values Kissinger as a reliable old friend because of his indelible contribution to introducing Washington's decades-old engagement policy. We hope he will continue to exert influence on US-China ties,” he said.

;

;In December 2016 – just a day after president-elect Donald Trump's unprecedented phone call with Taiwanese President Tsai Ing-wen, which threatened to upend the fragile balance in the Taiwan Strait – Xi sought Kissinger's advice during a meeting in Beijing.

;

;In his 2011 book On China, Kissinger recounted how he advised Deng on how to manage a diplomatic crisis following the bloody Tiananmen crackdown in 1989. He was invited to Beijing in a private capacity in November of that year.

;

;Zhiqun Zhu, an international relations professor at Bucknell University, said Kissinger, as a “hardcore realist”, tended to downplay ideology, values and human rights in foreign affairs and had been an advocate for stronger relations with China.

;

;At a 2021 event in New York, the US statesman warned against pushing China too hard on human rights – particularly Beijing's policies in Hong Kong and Xinjiang.

;

;“We should not use the human rights issue as a deliberate issue to undermine the existing structures, because if we do that, we will be in a permanent confrontation,” Kissinger said.

;

;Zhu said while Kissinger's legacy was more complicated and controversial in the US, where some have accused him of being a war criminal, he had been widely revered in China among Chinese officials, think tanks and scholars.

;

;“Generations of Chinese leaders have believed that Kissinger's role was unparalleled in the process of US-China normalisation. So he has been considered an 'old friend' by generations of Chinese leaders and remains popular in China,” Zhu said.

;

;However, Zhu noted Kissinger's views on China had shifted in recent years, coinciding with growing bipartisan antipathy towards Beijing in the US.

;

;“As the Soviet Union disintegrated and as Russian power continues to decline, the global centre has shifted from Europe to the Asia-Pacific, where China has emerged as the challenger to US dominance,” he said.

;

;“So increasingly Kissinger – like many other realists – views China as a threat to US interests. Still, he harbours a more benign view of US-China relations and does not favour a confrontational approach towards China.”

;

;George Magnus, a research associate at Oxford University's China Centre, said one of the reasons for Kissinger's sustained popularity among Chinese leaders was his image as being “friendlier, more accommodating and less bellicose” than many US officials.

;

;In an interview with CBS that aired earlier this month, Kissinger spoke positively of China's new-found role in mediating international conflicts such as the Ukraine war.

;

;“Now that China has entered the negotiation, it will come to a head, I think, by the end of the year,” Kissinger said. “We will be talking about negotiating processes and even actual negotiations.”

;

;Kissinger called for direct dialogue between Xi and US President Joe Biden in an interview with The Economist last month.

;

;“[If] the two presidents meet, rather than list all their grievances, which they know … hopefully the American president, from my point of view, would say: 'Mr President, the two greatest dangers to peace right now, are us two. In the sense that we have the capacity to destroy humanity. I think we should agree between ourselves to try to avoid such a situation',” he said.

;

;Magnus noted that while Kissinger was preoccupied with America's place in the world and winning a great power competition, he was also clearly worried about the growing likelihood of a superpower confrontation.

;

;“After all, as he says in The Economist interview, the US and China are uniquely equipped to both wage and prevent war. And the latter demands their urgent and relentless attention, is what I read in the piece,” he said.

;

;Kissinger marks 50 years since first China visit, urges US-China talks

;

;Kissinger's moderate pro-engagement views and occasional deference towards Chinese rulers are also easy targets for criticism among China hawks.

;

;While Kissinger said the 1989 Tiananmen crackdown was “too brutal”, he nonetheless praised Deng, who was widely blamed for the incident, as a “great reformer”.

;

;James Mann, author of About Face: A History of America's Curious Relationship with China, from Nixon to Clinton, criticised Kissinger for his depiction of Chinese leaders as “wise and farsighted”.

;

;China has remained the core of Kissinger's legacy, according to Mann, who was critical of his other accomplishments, including the detente with the Soviet Union and the peace deal with the communists in Vietnam – both of which were short-lived.

;

;Mann, who is also a member of the US-China Economic and Security Review Commission, said that while Kissinger continued to hold “intermittent influence” in the quarter century after the opening to China, he had “no influence” and “not much relevance” today.

;

;According to Mann, many Americans have been disappointed that Beijing's growing prosperity did not lead to a more open, less repressive China.

;

;“Back then, the threat of Soviet military power brought the two countries together. Today, China is supporting Russia as it wages war in Europe,” he said.

;

;Kissinger also admitted he had faced challenges in dealing with the Trump and Biden administrations. In an interview last year with the New York Post, he expressed frustration that he had not been invited to meet Biden, although he claimed to have had access to every president from Nixon to Trump.

;

;Carla Hills, a former US trade representative and housing secretary, defended Kissinger's achievements.

;

;“I think he's quite influential, and particularly in China. I think sitting down and talking the way Kissinger talks is enormously useful, and I don't think that we can go around saying we only want to deal with democratic governments,” she said.

;

;“And we get along with Vietnam, which is communist. So it isn't whether or not they're a democracy. The question is whether they follow the rules – that is the point. And that's something that Henry strongly believed in, and when you talk about diplomacy, he is the king of it.”

;

;Dennis Wilder, a research fellow at the Initiative for US-China Dialogue on Global Issues at Georgetown University, said Kissinger still held a unique and important place in US-China relations.

;

;“Chinese officials and academics have considered him an 'old friend' of China … With this residue of trust, the Chinese side is comfortable talking candidly with Kissinger and hoping that he will be able to get their thoughts through to the successive US administration,” he said.

;

;Kissinger warns China and US against escalating to all-out AI conflict

;

;But in the US, opinions of Kissinger varied greatly depending on who you ask, Wilder noted.

;

;“Many hardliners on China believe that the Nixon opening to China was a mistake because it has made Chinese communism strong by allowing it into world markets. Those who believe in stabilising US-China relations are much more inclined to listen to Kissinger's recommendations,” he said.

;

;Pang Zhongying, a professor of international affairs at Sichuan University noted that the public might never know the full scope of Kissinger's impact on history.

;

;“We know only a small part of him, and a great deal of his life's work, including his dealings with China, are among the most well-guarded secrets,” he said.

;

;“Kissinger's longevity is a miracle in itself, and as an old-fashioned realist, he remains pragmatic and hopeful. Despite his flawed legacy and many controversies, Kissinger is still among the most respected and influential foreign policy thinkers in the world.”
